docs.lead_paragraph: WHICH side are you on?'' goes an old union song. It's a question patients might be asking their doctors in the wake of the Supreme Court's decision, shielding health maintenance organizations from some lawsuits by patients in federal court. The case, Pegram v. Herdrich, concerned a woman whose appendix burst after she was made to wait eight days to take a diagnostic test for abdominal pain. She contended that her H.M.O., which, like many health plans, gave doctors financial incentives to hold down costs, improperly restricted patients' access to medical procedures.

headline.main: The Nation: The 'R' Word; Justice Souter Takes on a Health Care Taboo

docs.abstract: Review of Supreme Court unanimous ruling in Pegram v Herdich, case concerning a woman whose appendix burst after her HMO made her wait eight days for diagnostic test; finds that profit incentive to ration treatment is intrinsic to design and mission of HMO's, which have been approved by Congress since 1973, and is hence not open to challenge in federal court; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Natalie Davis Spingarn, a medical writer who endured multiple bouts of cancer and became a prominent spokeswoman for cancer survivors, died on June 6 in Washington. She was 78. The cause was pancreatic cancer, her son Jonathan said.

headline.main: Natalie D. Spingarn Dies at 78; Advocate for Cancer Survivors

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted unanimously today to approve a bill that catapults electronic commerce to a new level by allowing consumers and businesses to sign contracts online and know that their e-signature is just as binding as one in ink. The bill, which passed 87 to 0, has already been approved by the House and now goes to President Clinton, who said today that he would sign it into law.

headline.main: SENATE APPROVES BILL THAT ALLOWS ONLINE CONTRACTS

docs.abstract: Senate approves, 87-0, bill allowing consumer and businesses to sign contracts online and know that e-signature is just as binding as one in ink; law giving electronic signatures legal weight of paper signatures will enable consumers to sign legally enforceable contracts for health insurance, bank loans and brokerage accounts over Internet, around the clock and with no delay; financial institutions and insurance firms will save billions of dollars by eliminating paperwork and storing records electronically; bill allows consumers to choose whether to do business on paper or on-line; consumer advocates fear new frauds; Margot Saunders of Consumer Law Center warns that consumers will be left to 'prove a negative' if their signatures are forged (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate voted unanimously today to approve a bill that catapults electronic commerce to a new level by allowing consumers and businesses to sign contracts online and know that their e-signature is just as binding as one in ink.    The bill, which...

byline.original: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and JERI CLAUSING

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City hospitals, reeling from federal spending cuts and struggling to adapt to an era in which doctors' offices have replaced them as centers for many procedures, are desperately cutting their budgets. Some centers, notably Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, are laying off workers and scaling back medical departments. Others, like the city's public hospitals, are farming out functions like security. And executives at nearly every hospital, even those serving affluent communities, are turning a sharp eye to budgets, looking for things to trim or eliminate as they clamor for relief from Washington. ''Who else am I going to lay off around here?'' said Frederick D. Alley, the chief executive of Brooklyn Hospital Center. ''I have been at it for four years.''

headline.main: Workers Cut As Hospitals Tighten Belts

docs.abstract: Letter by health care analyst Kenneth S Abramowitz letter says every citizen should have to buy health insurance, states must allow 'bare bones' policies and government should subsidize costs for lower-income people; adds that if these policies were put into effect today there would be no uninsured Americans next week (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. indicated yesterday that negotiations to sell its financial services and international units to the ING Group, the Dutch financial services and insurance company, had hit a bump. Aetna said it had started talks with other possible buyers, which it did not identify, while continuing the negotiations with ING.

headline.main: Aetna Casts Some Doubt On ING Deal

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc's negotiations to sell its financial services and international units to ING Group hit a snag; starts talks with other possible buyers while continuing talks with ING (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PIORE-Nora Kahn. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health mourn the passing of its esteemed faculty member, Nora Kahn Piore. A professor of public health economics from 1972 to 1982, she enjoyed a varied career that spanned fifty years working on issues related to health insurance, health economics and policy analysis for New York City's Commissioners of Health, Hospitals and Welfare. To her children, grandchildren and sister, we extend deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, MD Dean

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIORE, NORA KAHN
